article:
'Circular DNA' is a form of DNA that is found in viruses, bacteria and archaea
as well as in eukaryotic cells in the form of either mitochondrial DNA or
plastid DNA.

While the individual strands of a linear double helix represent two distinct and
separable molecules, this need not be true for 'circular DNA'. If the strands
twist an odd number of times around one another in completing the DNA loop, then
they are covalently joined into a single molecule.
